feed.title: Survivor Interview: Winner Sophie Clarke
feed.subtitle: The Survivor: South Pacific winner reveals how she used religion as a manipulation tactic, why she feels she was undersold by the show's editing and what she plans on doing with her new riches.

content.div:
When Survivor: South Pacific began, it would have been a long shot to bet on 22-year-old Sophie Clarke to take the $1 million prize. Thirty-nine grueling days on the island later, the medical student from Willsboro, N.Y. was sitting in the final three next to early favourite and returning contestant Coach, making her case against her tribe's spiritual leader as well as their alliance partner Albert. And there she was, made up on a soundstage as host Jeff Probst announced that she'd won the 23rd season of Survivor by a staggering 6-3-0 vote, making her an instant millionaire. Speaking to Dose.ca less than 24 hours after her victory, Clarke reveals how she used religion as a manipulation tactic, why she feels she was undersold by the show's editing and what she plans on doing with her new riches.

So, how does it feel to be a millionaire?

It feels like a million bucks!

You had some time to think between the final tribal council on the island and the results reveal in California. What was going

through your mind?

I thought I'd done pretty well, I thought I'd won. I thought I'd actually won by one more vote; I was surprised that Coach got three. I never knew for sure, I was so nervous when the third vote came up I thought I hadn't won. The whole thing was so nerve-wracking.

But you were pretty sure you'd won?

Yeah, I felt like in the tribal council I think I was the only one who had something positive said to them.

On the show, you didn't really emerge as a strong character ‘til much later in the season. Do you feel you were portrayed accurately?

I think that what they showed of me was true. I do feel like I did a lot more strategically that they didn't show. I had a final three alliance with Albert and Rick that was never shown; I had a final alliance with Edna the whole game that was never shown. So I think there was a lot more involved, in terms of thinking strategically, that was never shown.

It seems that a lot of the strategizing that you and Albert did was cut in favour of the Coach vs. Ozzy storyline.

Right. They had so much to show our season -- that, Cochran doing whatever Cochran does and Ozzy catching fish -- that it was, ah, jam packed.

I get the impression that you feel you were undersold.

It's strange. I've been doing interviews all day and I feel like I find myself almost defending my win, which is not what I feel like I should do. I don't like that people feel like it was framed as a Coach loses situation. So [being undersold] is the only explanation for that – unless I'm incorrect in how much control I had over the game.

Coach thought he had the season in the bag. Since the two of you were so close, has your win put a strain on your friendship?

Coach and I were very close out there. If I got second place I would be bitter. He thinks that he should have won and I disagree and that's an awkward thing to have in a friendship, especially when you throw a million dollars into the mix. Coach and Ozzy both seemed very sad last night.

Coach seemed to preach the idea of playing the game the way you would act in life. How much of life on the game did you bring back to your real life?

I think everybody's different. I really left everything there. I think the people that treated the game out there like real life, like Coach, for them they brought it back. For me, it was one giant monopoly game.

Do you feel that's the smart strategy?

I think the majority of people that go on Survivor say, "I'm going to do what it takes to win." I know if I was on the jury that's what I would want to hear. I'd want to hear somebody fess up and say, "Look, this is what I did and this is how I got away with it."

I think people didn't want to hear apologies; they didn't want to hear about honesty and integrity and that was both Coach's and Albert's downfall. They forgot that it was a game and they needed to show how they played and instead they treated it like real life.

This season more than any other religion was a factor. Are you as religious as you portrayed yourself to be or was that a strategy?

I recognized very early on the benefits of the intensity of religion in my tribe. I recognized that it was a controlling force and if Brandon and Coach and Albert and Rick even all thought they were answering to God in Survivor and if they backstabbed each other and me they would go to hell then that was fantastic, because for me there was no repercussions. Survivor to me was "go crazy, do what you want, stab someone in the back" and they did have that approach which made them the perfect people to align with.

When it came to the religious thing, I think that it got out of hand but I don't think anyone maliciously manipulated anyone with religion.

Not even Coach?

Um…in his real life Coach is a pastor, he preaches every week. In his own words, he has a lot of inner demons – he and Brandon both do – but I think they fuelled each other. I think Coach justifies a lot of what he does but I do think Coach and Brandon are both well meaning, if a bit naive.

Throughout the show there were several times when your name was brought up at tribal council. Did you ever think you were not going to make it to the end?

I was never worried at a tribal council. I always knew when my name was going to come up and I never thought I'd be voted off. But it is strange to see people debate your demise on television.

Finally, what are you doing to do with the million dollars?

I'm in medical school so I've got a lot of bills to pay. I'm looking for any advice on how to spend it.
